chapter.title: Operators and expressions
chapter.para: In python most of the lines you will write will be expressions. Expressions are made of operators and operands. An expression is like 2 + 3 .

section.title: Operators
section.para: Operators are the symbols which tells the python interpreter to do some mathematical or logical operation. Few basic examples of mathematical operators are given below:
To get floating result you need to the division using any of operand as floating number. To do modulo operation use % operator

section.title: quadraticequation.py
section.para: This is a program to evaluate the quadratic equation
section.screen: #!/usr/bin/env python import math a = int(raw_input("Enter value of a: ")) b = int(raw_input("Enter value of b: ")) c = int(raw_input("Enter value of c: ")) d = b * b - 4 * a * c if d < 0: print "ROOTS are imaginary" else: root1 = (-b + math.sqrt(d)) / (2.0 * a) root2 = (-b - math.sqrt(d)) / (2.0 * a) print "Root 1 = ", root1 print "Root 2 = ", root2

section.title: salesmansalary.py
section.para: In this example we are going to calculate the salary of a camera salesman. His basic salary is 1500, for every camera he will sell he will get 200 and the commission on the month's sale is 2 %. The input will be number of cameras sold and total price of the cameras.
section.screen:
#!/usr/bin/env python basic_salary = 1500 bonus_rate = 200 commision_rate = 0.02 numberofcamera = int(raw_input("Enter the number of inputs sold: ")) price = float(raw_input("Enter the total prices: ")) bonus = (bonus_rate * numberofcamera) commision = (commision_rate * numberofcamera * price)
print "Bonus = %6.2f" % bonus print "Commision = %6.2f" % commision print "Gross salary = %6.2f" % ( basic_salary + bonus + commision)
section.para: The output
section.screen: [kd@kdlappy book]$ ./salesmansalary.py Enter the number of inputs sold: 5 Enter the total prices: 20450 Bonus = 1000.00 Commision = 2045.00 Gross salary = 4545.00
